title: Is there any easy way to define a field in big struct by IDA?

comments.text: One way you can go about this is instead of declaring the byte array in-line, simply declare a union in its place. One member of the union will be a byte array the maximum size of the struct you uncovered (as you had), the other member will be a newly defined struct with the evolving view of the structure as you learn more about it.
@0xC0000022L For the newly defined struct in the union, how can I specific a field with a offset directly, instead of thinking about placing gaps before and after it?

answers_data.content:
This specific case looks like that you have an array of other structures (or sequential similar structures, but according to using the 
+
it is unlikely because it is standard pattern for accessing the array) inside the structure in question. It is possible (and very much likely because of the size of the gap between them) that capability change reasons are also members of these structures. The size of the inner structure should be 3936 (a value that is multiplied by family), and it starts somewhere inside the first Gap field. In this case I would create a separate type for the inner structure, and place the array of 2 such structures inside the main structure according to the use of inner fields inside (you can check assembly code that accesses both capability change reasons for that).

comments.text: This is a viable solution, but it would be better if IDA provided a progressive field definition feature. As 0xC0000022L pointed out in the comments, union is an option, but this feature IDA can clearly do better, and this feature is what most people need (at least i think so).

answers_data.content:
If you're okay with scripting, the ida-minsc plugin that I maintain at https://github.com/arizvisa/ida-minsc allows for slice assignments and other things that might help with contiguous layout of structures and other things. The following is just me pasting your structure into a database, dumping its contents, adding an enumeration. Afterwards, I updated it (using the UI) with your new structure. 
Python>st=struc.by('NCSI_INTERFACE_ATTRIBUTES')

Python>st.members

[0]    0+0x3250 BYTE[12880] 'Gap' [(, 1), 12880]

Python>enum.new('NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON')
0xff003556

Python>st.members

[0]    0+0x8                      NET_LUID_LH 'InterfaceLuid'            
[1]    8+0x10                            GUID 'InterfaceGuid'            
[2]   18+0x11a0                    BYTE[4512] 'Gap'                      [(, 1), 4512]
[3] 11b8+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV4' (, 4)
[4] 11bc+0xf5c                     BYTE[3932] 'Gap1'                     [(, 1), 3932]
[5] 2118+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV6' (, 4)
[6] 211c+0x1134                    BYTE[4404] 'Gap2'                     [(, 1), 4404]
Next, I selected the member to modify, and then replaced it using a 
BYTE[4508]
and a 4-byte integer. 
Python>st.members[2:3]
[]

Python>st.members[2:3] = ['BYTE[4508]', (int,4)]

Python>st.members

[0]    0+0x8                      NET_LUID_LH 'InterfaceLuid'            
[1]    8+0x10                            GUID 'InterfaceGuid'            
[2]   18+0x119c                    BYTE[4508] 'field_18'                 [(, 1), 4508]
[3] 11b4+0x4                              int 'field_11B4'               (, 4)
[4] 11b8+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV4' (, 4)
[5] 11bc+0xf5c                     BYTE[3932] 'Gap1'                     [(, 1), 3932]
[6] 2118+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV6' (, 4)
[7] 211c+0x1134                    BYTE[4404] 'Gap2'                     [(, 1), 4404]
I wasn't sure about the other field you're trying to split (as it looks like an array with some variations between them), but you can subtract the base offset from this object to get a quick calculation out of it. In the following, I'm subtracting the array multiple (3936) to translate the offset of that "gap" field across 0. Afterwards, I use the translated offsets of both members (-0xf48 and 0x254) to do another slice assignment. 
Python>st.members - 3936

[0] -f60+0x8                      NET_LUID_LH 'InterfaceLuid'            
[1] -f58+0x10                            GUID 'InterfaceGuid'            
[2] -f48+0x119c                    BYTE[4508] 'field_18'                 [(, 1), 4508]
[3]  254+0x4                              int 'field_11B4'               (, 4)
[4]  258+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV4' (, 4)
[5]  25c+0xf5c                     BYTE[3932] 'Gap1'                     [(, 1), 3932]
[6] 11b8+0x4    NCSI_CAPABILITY_CHANGE_REASON 'CapabilityChangeReasonV6' (, 4)
[7] 11bc+0x1134                    BYTE[4404] 'Gap2'                     [(, 1), 4404]

Python>st.members[2:3] = ['_BYTE[0xf48]', '_BYTE[0x254]']

Python>st.members

[0]    0+0x8                      NET_LUID_LH 'InterfaceLuid'            
[1]    8+0x10                            GUID 'InterfaceGuid'

[8] 211c+0x1134                    BYTE[4404] 'Gap2'                     [(, 1), 4404]
Slice assignments in this thing work with lists of types. So that includes IDAPython's 
struc_t
and 
member_t
as well as the wrapped types that I've been using throughout this answer. The following is just an example of using random things to extend the structure. It's using 2 floats, an 8-element array of 2-byte ints, a 
GUID
(fetched using the old IDAPython structure api), and a copy of the same structure's last 2 members (7..9). For reference, the new members start at offset 0x3250. 
Python>st.members[9:9] = [float]*2 + [ [(int,2), 8] ]+ [idaapi.get_struc(idaapi.get_struc_id('GUID'))] + st.members[7:]
